name: Sanicula aqua
Relationship: Compare: ABROT.; ALUM.; CALC.; SIL.; SULPH. Sanicula Aqua must not be confounded with the Sanicle (pool-root or wood marsh), also called SANICULA. This is used in various nervous affections, resembling Valeriana. It is used as a vulnerary, resolvent for sanguineous extravasations, and as an astringent. Has not been proved.)

Head: Photophobia
Dread of downward motion
Soreness behind ears
Lachrymation in cold air or from cold application
Profuse scaly dandruff
Profuse sweat on occiput and in nape of neck, during sleep
Stomach: Is vomited as soon as it reaches the stomach
Rectum: Excoriation of skin about anus, perineum, and genitals
Diarrhoea; changeable in character and color; after eating
No desire until a large accumulation
After great straining only partially expelled; recedes, crumbles at verge of anus
Back: Dislocated feeling in sacrum and better lying on right side
Mouth: Tongue large, flabby, burning; must protrude it to keep cool
Female: Leucorrhoea with odor of fish-brine or old cheese
Bearing-down, as if contents of pelvis would escape; better, rest

details: Has been found a useful remedy in enuresis, seasickness, constipation, etc. Rickets.
Natural History: The Water of Sanicula Springs, Ottawa, Ill.
